ul: Microsoft® Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) 3.5 Microsoft Visual Studio® 2008

It can only be consumed by WCF enabled clients. Supports the WS* stack including reliable messaging, and secure transactions. It only supports transport security; you cannot turn on message security. The service can be hosted in IIS 5.0 or IIS 6.0, but it is not message activated, hence you can consider hosting in a Windows service or IIS 7.0 instead. Your only authentication option is Windows.

For more information on bindings, see “Windows Communication Foundation Bindings” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733027.aspxFor binding Q&A, see the Binding section of “WCF 3.5 Questions and Answers “ at http://www.codeplex.com/WCFSecurityGuide/Wiki/View.aspx?title=WCF%20Questions%20and%20Answers%20%28Q%26A%29&referringTitle=Home

It only supports transport security; you cannot turn on message security.
The service can be hosted in IIS 5.0 or IIS 6.0, but it is not message activated, hence you can consider hosting in a Windows service or IIS 7.0 instead.
Your only authentication option is Windows.
For more information on bindings, see “Windows Communication Foundation Bindings” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733027.aspx

p: If you need to support WCF clients on the same machine as your service, consider using the netNamedPipeBinding.
The netNamedPipeBinding has the following characteristics:
Use this binding when you want to make use of the NamedPipe protocol and provide full support for SOAP security, transactions, and reliability.
The following example shows how to configure netNamedPipeBinding:

pre: <system.serviceModel>....    <services>        <service behaviorConfiguration="" name="WCFServicecHost.MyService">            ...            <endpoint address="" binding="netNamedPipeBinding" bindingConfiguration=""                name="namedPipeBinding" contract="WCFServicecHost.IMyService" />            ...        </service>    </services></system.serviceModel>

html:
Applies to

  • Microsoft® Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) 3.5
  • Microsoft Visual Studio® 2008

What to Do

If you need to support WCF clients on the same machine as your service, consider using the netNamedPipeBinding.

Why

The netNamedPipeBinding has the following characteristics:

  • It can only be consumed by WCF enabled clients.
  • Supports the WS* stack including reliable messaging, and secure transactions.
  • It only supports transport security; you cannot turn on message security.
  • The service can be hosted in IIS 5.0 or IIS 6.0, but it is not message activated, hence you can consider hosting in a Windows service or IIS 7.0 instead.
  • Your only authentication option is Windows.

When

Use this binding when you want to make use of the NamedPipe protocol and provide full support for SOAP security, transactions, and reliability.

How

The following example shows how to configure netNamedPipeBinding:

<system.serviceModel>
....
    <services>
        <service behaviorConfiguration="" name="WCFServicecHost.MyService">
            ...
            <endpoint address="" binding="netNamedPipeBinding" bindingConfiguration=""
                name="namedPipeBinding" contract="WCFServicecHost.IMyService" />
            ...
        </service>
    </services>
</system.serviceModel>

Additional Resources

  • For more information on bindings, see “Windows Communication Foundation Bindings” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733027.aspx
  • For binding Q&A, see the Binding section of “WCF 3.5 Questions and Answers “ at http://www.codeplex.com/WCFSecurityGuide/Wiki/View.aspx?title=WCF%20Questions%20and%20Answers%20%28Q%26A%29&referringTitle=Home

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
